awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Microlocal Concentration and Propagation in Spectral Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
In nature, solutions of wave-type equations appear in phenomena as far reaching as wave functions of quantum particles, the acoustics of concert halls, and scattering of gravitational waves.  In these situations, there are certain fundamental frequencies and vibrational modes associated to the underlying geometry of the space.  These frequencies and modes play an essential role in the understanding of the behavior of wave phenomena. They appear, for example, in the acoustical design of concert halls and the vibration of instruments.  This project develops tools, based on propagation phenomena, to study the delicate relationship between the geometry of the space and behavior of the corresponding modes. 

This research will provide new insight into the structure of vibrational modes for general spaces.  Many quantitative regularity results (as measured by L^p norms) are already known for spaces with non-positive curvature.  However, these types of estimates are unavailable under less restrictive geometric assumptions.  The main goals of this project are two fold: (1) to describe the concentration phenomena that result in L^p norm growth for individual modes, and (2) to use this understanding to produce estimates for modes and frequencies based solely on dynamical properties of the underlying manifold.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Solutions to the Helmholtz equation play a crucial role in nature, informing the behavior of quantum particles' wave functions, the profiles of vibrating membranes, and the acoustics of concert halls. Prior to the grant, the PI and J.Galkowski developed new techniques to understand the behavior of Helmholtz solutions by studying their concentration and propagation using microlocal analysis. Over the course of the grant, the PI executed a program to improve and extend these methods through applications to problems including geometric bounds on igenfunction concentration, remainder estimates for Weyl laws with applications to random wave models, and Lp norms and averages of Laplace eigenfunctions.

The three main outcomes of this grant are described below and were obtained in collaboration with J. Galkowski.

One of the achievements, and goal, of this grant was establishing quantitative improvements on Weyl Law remainders under dynamical assumptions on the geodesic flow. One of the oldest problems in spectral theory is to understand how eigenvalues distribute on the real line. A consequence of this project is that an improved remainder for the eigenvalue counting function holds on all product manifolds. The results also include logarithmic gains on asymptotics for the off-diagonal two-point Weyl Law under the assumption that the set of geodesics that pass near both points has a small measure.

The previous work made it possible to develop a roadmap for obtaining quantitative improvements for the Weyl Law that hold for most Riemannian metrics. This result was one of the goals in the proposal and is expected to have a great impact in the field.

We proved that for most Riemannian metrics with which one can endow a compact Riemannian manifold, the following two assertions hold: 1) the number of primitive closed geodesics of length smaller than a parameter has a stretched exponential upper bound that grows with the parameter. 2) The error term in the Weyl Law for the eigenvalue counting function has a logarithmic improvement over the standard bound.

In particular, we now have a roadmap for establishing that there are quantitatively improved L∞ bounds for Laplace eigenfunctions that hold for most Riemannian metrics. This was another goal of the proposal.

Another significant result of this grant was the development of geodesic beam techniques to study the growth of high Lp norms for eigenfunctions. Its completion was one of the goals of the proposal. In 1988, C. Sogge established upper bounds on the growth of the Lp norms for a general compact Riemannian manifold. In collaboration with J. Galkowski, we found general dynamical conditions guaranteeing quantitative improvements in Lp estimates for p above the critical threshold. These were the first results improving estimates for the Lp growth of eigenfunctions that only require dynamical assumptions. In contrast with previous improvements, our assumptions are local in the sense that they depend only on the geodesics passing through a shrinking neighborhood of a given set.
